data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mealtimes are not only a means to provide patients with adequate nutrition but also an opportunity to support social interaction. Food, and the service of food, is now regarded as an essential part of treatment and the therapeutic benefit of food within the healing process cannot be underestimated.

Up to 40% of adults show signs of malnutrition on admission to hospital and often their stay exacerbates their condition. This is due to lack of nutrition resulting from insufficient food, an unbalanced diet and/or defective assimilation. Certain groups of patients, such as the elderly, have particular dietary and eating requirements that need to be met to prevent malnutrition and to aid recovery.

The ward environment, presentation of food and the timing and content of meals are important elements in encouraging patients to eat well. The importance of mealtimes needs to be re-emphasised and ward based staff given the opportunity to focus on the nutritional requirements of patients at meal times with minimum distraction.
In addition there are a number of documents that support the implementation of protected mealtimes,
Care Quality Commission Fundamental Standard : service users food and hydration needs must be met
Hospital Food Standards Panel Report (2014)
10 key Characteristics of Good Nutritional Care NPSA (2009)
Malnutrition Task Force Action Plan (2013)
What does good nutritional care look like (NHS England 2013)
PLACE (Patient Led Assessment of the Care Environment) (2013)
Nutrition and Hydration Digest nd Edition (2017)
NPSA (2007)
Still Hungry to be Heard (Age UK, 2010)

The provision of protected mealtimes allows nutritional care to be safely delivered, maintains nutrition and hydration of patients, which in turn can reduce falls, prevent pressure ulcers, prevent and treat urinary tract infections, whilst improving the quality of care and patient experience.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Protect patient mealtimes from unnecessary interruptions by limiting ward based activities to only those deemed relevant to mealtimes or ‘essential' clinical care
Provide the nursing team with time to devote to the delivery of food and nutrition and to ensure that patients' cultural needs are fully met at these times.
Allow nurses to provide assistance and to observe patients at mealtimes
Improve the mealtime experience of patients by providing an environment that is conducive to eating, welcoming, clean and tidy.
Definitions

table_items.text: This is a period of time when all routine (non-urgent) activity within in-patient wards ceases or is reduced as far as is practicable, in order that nursing staff can serve, assist and supervise patients with their meals and drinks.

This is a means of easily identifying patients on the ward who require assistance with their nutritional or fluid intake, those at nutritional risk or those patients that require close monitoring of their nutritional intake. The use of a red tray / red jug lid is advocated to highlight to nursing and Patient Services Assistants those patients who require specific assistance, observation or require a modified fluid / diet.
Nutrition Alert and Risk Management Board
Allows essential information to be communicated in a timely and effective manner at the bedside.

Nutrition and Hydration Strategy Group (Basildon)

are responsible for ensuring a safe and improved meal time experience for the benefit of patients, and also to approve and implement changes that are agreed locally
Chief Executive - as the Accountable Officer, is responsible for the safety and quality of care provided by the Trust. They will delegate this responsibility to the Directors of Nursing.
Director of Nursing – The Director of Nursing is responsible for the development of this policy, ensuring that all in-patient wards are practicing protected patient
mealtimes and that wards and departments are compliant with the standards within this policy.
Medical Director will ensure that medical staff are aware of the need to adhere to this policy and ensure that all non-urgent clinical work ceases during protected mealtimes

Heads of Nursing / Midwifery have operational responsibility for the implementation of the policy and ensuring that the Directorate management teams are fully informed and aware of the importance of protected mealtimes
Matrons have responsibility for the implementation and monitoring ward and department compliance against the standards set out in this policy.
They will ensure that Ward Managers are fully supported and understand the importance of implementing and monitoring this Policy.

Monitoring will include participation in audits of clinical areas, utilising performance management techniques with Senior Sisters and Ward Managers to continuously improve practice in relation to this initiative.
Ward Managers / Senior Sisters will ensure that ward routines / plans facilitate where appropriate and maximise protected mealtimes for patients
Ensure a practical strategy is in place if protected mealtimes- are not complied with Monitor the ward compliance with this policy
Ensure that all patients, relatives and all visitors to the ward are aware of the protected mealtime policy
Organising the ward teams' mealtimes to ensure the maximum number of staff are available to deliver and assist patients with their food
Recording the non-adherence to the policy to enable monitoring and identification of areas for improvement
Makes best interest judgements for any exclusion from the policy for specific patients/ situations.

Registered Nurses are responsible for ensuring that food delivery to patients is a priority during mealtimes, assessing patients who are nutritionally at risk; providing assistance and encouraging patients to eat and documenting how much food is eaten
Identifying patients who require assistance with eating or need adaptive cutlery and documenting their requirements.
Ensuring that nursing staff are available to assist their patients to eat Ensuring that details of nutrition status are recorded on the white boards above the patient beds

Ensuring relatives are aware of Protected Mealtime policy and are offered the opportunity to assist their family member with feeding, if the patient is in agreement. Where the patient may not have the capacity to make decisions staff have to act in the patient's best interests.
Health Care Assistants will provide assistance to patients who require toileting facilities and hand hygiene prior to the service of food
Ensure the bedside table is clear of patient associated items such as vomit bowls/ urine bottles
Provide assistance to patients who require help to eat and drink
Ward Hostess / Housekeeper will ensure that patients are comfortable prior to the service of food
Ensure that the meals are served within comfortable reach of the patient
Make sure those patients who require help with feeding are issued a ‘Red Tray' to ensure timely assistance
Other Healthcare workers / Allied Health Professionals / Multidisciplinary team will only perform clinical interventions if they are clinically appropriate or cannot be undertaken at any other time.
Ensure that nursing staff are available to assist their patients to eat
Ensure that clinical interventions and care delivery is performed around the patients need for a protected mealtime
Process Mealtimes
Environment
Patients should be able to eat their food in a relaxed environment, at their own pace and rest afterwards.

5.1.1 A quiet and relaxed atmosphere on the ward should be created by closing the ward entrance doors, putting the locking mechanism on if necessary. If patients are using a day room facility, ensure the room is warm and welcoming, clean and tidy.
5.1.2 Provide an undisturbed mealtime for patients, by reducing noise e.g. no cleaning equipment should be in use, ensure patient choice for use of radio or television systems.
5.1.3 Ensure notices are displayed on the ward explaining protected mealtimes so all staff, patients and visitors understand the importance of mealtimes as part of care and treatment for patients.
5.1.4 Bed tables and eating areas should be cleared of items not part of or conducive to mealtimes e.g. urinals, vomit bowls, magazines.
Interruptions
5.2.1 Clinical activities should be limited to those that are relevant to mealtimes or absolutely essential at that time.
5.2.2 Interruptions to patients e.g. ward round, doctors' visits, cleaning, documentation or therapy should only occur in exceptional circumstances.

5.2.3 Ensure relatives adhere to visiting times which are set outside protected mealtimes. However, if a family member or carer wishes to provide support with assisting or supervising a patient, this should be encouraged.
Note - Open visiting remains in place for patients where this has been negotiated between family carers and the Senior Sister / Nurse-in-Charge.
Organisation of mealtimes

5.3.2 Prepare staff by establishing who will be involved in the mealtime and who will answer any patient call bells, telephones etc. so that staff directly involved with patients at mealtimes can focus on the patients requiring assistance or supervision.

5.3.3 Getting patients ready by ensuring the dining table or bed table is clean and appropriately set with use of trays, serviette, appropriate cutlery (including adapted cutlery as required), condiments and a drink of water.

5.3.4 Positioning patients where they can eat safely, maintaining their privacy and dignity. Staff must ensure that the patient is seated at the correct height to reach food from the table. If the patient is nursed in bed, then nursing staff must ensure, prior to the serving of food, that the patient is positioned so that they can reach their meal. Reasonable adjustments should be made for those who are required to remain flat, such as spinal patients.
5.3.5 Ensure patient's hands are washed with soap and water or wipes provided for the purpose of hand cleansing
5.3.6 Nursing and other staff involved with the mealtime will wear a disposable apron to serve meals and assist patients
Exclusions

There will be occasions when it is not possible to reduce activity on the ward. NB. Nurses providing escort, or taking / collecting patients from other departments will reduce the overall numbers of nurses participating in the mealtime and offering help to patients. This should be taken into consideration by the RN supervising the mealtime. These include:-
Any acute medical emergency
Emergency and urgent care needs of patients will take precedence over protected mealtimes.
A&E / AMU / SAU transfers to wards
Where possible, transfer of patients should occur outside of mealtimes.
Where this is not possible, the nurse responsible for the transfer must liaise directly with the Nurse in Charge of the receiving ward.
Endoscopic procedures

Transfer of patients for planned and emergency endoscopic procedures will continue during protected mealtimes to prevent unnecessary delays to the patient pathway and disruption to procedure schedules. Meals should be saved for the patients return.
Invasive/Non-Invasive imaging procedures

Transfer of patients for planned and urgent Imaging procedures such as CT/ MRI, ultrasonic scans and videofluroscopy will continue during protected mealtimes to prevent unnecessary delays to the patient pathway and disruption to procedure schedules, meals should be saved for the patients return.
Urgent and Prescribed Treatments

Urgent and prescribed treatments such as blood transfusions and intravenous infusions, urgent blood tests and Point of Care testing (such as blood sugar monitoring) will not be interrupted on the basis of protected meal times.
Other activities that are unavoidable should be discussed with the Nurse-in- Charge of the ward.
Deceased patients

When a patient has died, it is preferable to avoid removal of the body at mealtimes. However, there are circumstances when this is not possible and the porters should take direction from the Nurse-in-Charge of the ward at the time.
